superior taste and smokeability" at the lowest levels of tar and

nicotine.

New Merit Ultima sets a new standard for the lowest" segment
of - the premium market. It offers a flavor alternative to Carlton and
Now smokers as well as to smokers who are interested in switching
to a cigarette at the super ultra light level. By using Merit's patented
enriched flavor technology and a new dual concentric filter, Merit
Ultima offers the great taste heritage of its parent brand and a
smooth, easy draw. And, Merit Ultima is the first cork-tipped entry

in the category.

Merit Ultima kings contain 1 mg. tar and 0.1 mg. of nicotine;

and 100's contain 2 mg. tar and 0.2 mg. of nicotine.

July 7, 1970

G. F. Todd, Esq.
Tobacco Research Council
Glen House, Stag Place
London, S.W.1
England

Dear Mr. Todd:

In recent talks with Dr. Carl G. Baker, Director
of the National Cancer Institute, the desirability
of forming an international stucy group concerned
with research into tobacco and health problems
was discussed. This letter is to invite you on
behalf of your organization to participate in this
The proceedings will aim at providing the relatively
few active investigators in tobacco. and health
research programs with an opportunity to discuss
freely current and future research prograns with
the intent of reaching connon objectives more quickly.
The group will be composed of investigators primarily
involved in tobacco and health research oriented towards
producing less harmful smoking products. The partici-
pants must be both willing and able to share with
other investigators what is being learned from their
current activities and openly discuss plans for future
research in the field. It is thought that by bringing
such a group of experts together to review ongoing
studies and to plan future investigations jointly less
harmful tobacco products will be available sooner and
costly research projects will not be duplicated unneces-
sarily. The meetings would be held at yearly intervals
with the different organizations acting as host.

information and study group.

ETAL

Karen Kerrigan
President

Small Business Survival Committee

Karen Kerrigan is president of the 40,000 member Small Business Survival
Committee (SBSC), a nationwide nonprofit, nonpartisan small business advocacy
organization representing America's small business and entrepreneunal sector. SBSC
works to promote policies and retorms which foster economic growth and

entrepreneurship.

Ms. Kerrigan is a nationally recognized spokesperson on a wide range of public
policy issues, who has testified numerous times on behalf of small business interests before
the U.S. Congress. She has appeared on such television programs as CNBC'S America's
Talking Network, C-SPAN, The Wall Street. Journal Report, European Business News,
The Home Business Show, NET's Capitol Watch and writes a twice-monthly syndicated
column for the American City Business Journals, an influential network of more than sixty

local business journals nationwide.

Ms. Kerrigan also serves as president of the Small Business Survival Foundation, a
research and education organization that studies the impact of government policy on
entrepreneurship and economic growth. She is also a principal in Capitol Hill Research, a

political and economic research service.

SBSC, which was recognized by Your Company magazine as one of the most
powerful small business lobbying groups in Washington, D.C., has been cited by Investor's
Business Daily, The Wall Street. Journal, The Washington Times, The Washington Post,
The New York Times, National Journal, Business Week, Entrepreneur, Fortune
Magazine, Bloomberg Business News, The Boston Herald, The Philadelphia Inquirer,
The Rush Limbaugh Show, The Michael Regan Show and hundreds oflocal newspapers.

INEUVS

RAMM ASSUMES LEADERSHIP OF
COUNCIL FOR TOBACCO RESEARCH

New York - H.H. Ramm, a long-time tobacco industry
executive, has been elected chairman and president of The
Council for Tobacco Research-U.S.A., Inc. He had been act-
ing chairman for the last two years. Recently he retired
from R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C.
Ramm, a native of Chicago, received his undergraduate
education at the University of Minnesota and was graduated
from Harvard Law School in 1929. He practiced law in New
York City until 1946 and then joined the R.J. Reynolds
Tobacco Company in Winston-Salem as solicitor and assist-
ant to the chairman of the board. He was elected a direc-
tor of the company in 1946, became general counsel in 1955,
and a vice president in 1970. In 1970, when R.J. Reynolds
Industries was formed, he became chairman of the executive
committee, senior vice president, general counsel, and a
director. He held these positions until his retirement on

December 31, 1970.

The Council for Tobacco Research had its origin in 1954
when representatives of tobacco manufacturers, growers and
warehousemen organized the Tobacco Industry Research Com-
mittee to support research by independent scientists into
all aspects of tobacco use and health. The research pro-
gram is the responsibility of a Scientific Advisory Board,
currently consisting of 10 noted physicians and scientists,
which has so far awarded grants to 251 scientists for a total

2a

of more than $17,000, 000.

Introduction

I have read the draft of this report, and in general I' am
impressed with the thoroughness with which the authors have
addressed the issues raised. Unfortunately, lack of time does
not permit me to respona to all of it, but there are some
sections of the report where I have put my comments in
writing. These comments cover inconsistencies in the report,
some possible methodological errors, and a number of
My specific comments follow, divided into two sections (the
more substative points coming first). Within each section,
the order in which the points are presented follows their
position in the report, and does not reflect their importance.
In a number of cases, attention to the issues raised would, in
my view, improve the quality of the final report. I would
particularly draw attention to points 1.9, 1.10 and 1.1.

typographical errors.

Substantive points

1.1 (page 5-9, lines 13-12 from bottom). Figure 5-1 is said
to show (v]alues of the test statistics (the standardized log
odds ratio ..) : plotted'. In fact this figure does no such
thing; it appears instead to be a plot of the p-values
associated with these test statistics. The actual values of
the log odds ratios are not indicated in the figure. To show
both the log ORS chemselves and their associated P-values
would need a two-dimensional plot; the associated normal
distribution could still be shown along the appropriate
1.2 (page 5-9, second paragraph, and Table 5-8). It is not
clear to me why the relative weights have been made to sum to
100 within countries. For countries with only one study (eg
Scotland) this means the entry in Table 5-8 is non-
informative. Presentation of the absolute weight would be
1.3 (page 5-10, lines 1-5). The first sentence here is
rather unclear at first. I assume that what is meant is that
for any value of x (where x is the list of p-values given in
the report: 0.5, 0.4 etc.) the observed number of studies with
a P-value less than x is significantly larger than the
number of studies involved). I think it would be better to
use the word 'studies' than 'outcomes', and to say 'as large
here are not independent, and although no claim is made that
they are, neither is any warning given that they are not.
Finally, I am not convinced by the statement that '(the)
conclusion is not attributable to a few extreme outcomes that
might be aberrant in some way'. If there were enough of such

I. TRADESCANTIA STAMEN HAIR MUTATION ASSAY

A preliminary experiment was carried out to evaluate the potential biologi-
cal activity of cigarette smoke products. The plant cuttings were exposed
to 2R1 CSC by inflorescences immersion and by direct exposure in a chamber.
The inflorescences were immersed in 5% DMSO containing 0, 0.05, 0.5 and 5
mg CSC/ml for 3 h at room temperature. Direct exposure was made to smoke
Data from this experiment are currently being analyzed; they will be
reported later. However, preliminary analysis of the data indicate that

An experiment treating V79 cells with dry impaction trapped CSC from 2R1
cigarettes, in the presence of Aroclor-induced rat liver S9, has been
completed and is presently being scored. The results of this experiment
will be compared to those obtained previously when testing the same CSC
Graphic and statistical techniques for data analysis and presentation are
being evaluated to determine which are most applicable and bi0logically
New equipment and facilities for tissue culture and>SCE experiments were

be fully operational.
III. 32-P-LABELING OF DNA ADDUCTS3

The analysis of a second DMS-DSD-DNA experiment has been completed. A
control USD-DNA sample, which had not been incubated with DMSO, also con-
tained the same additional spots, in the same location, as did a sample of
DSD-DNA incubated in 50% DMSO. This indicates that exposure to DMSO had
not been responsible for the additional spots present on the control plate
reported last month.* The two dimensional TLC-AR pattern of the 50% CSC- l
DSD-DNA sample again had a single, additional spot. The location of this g
spot was identical to the CSC specific spot obtained from the initial a H
experiment performed last month. Included in this experiment were addi- A
tional controls which indicated the spot was not due to a CSC specific E

CORESTA 1982 SYMPOSIUM
ABSTRACT FORM

AUTHOR(S) (indicate presenting author):

J. G. Nepomuceno (presenting), A. G. Kallianos, J. E. Wickham, and A. E. Stagg
Philip Morris Research Center, P. 0. Box 26583, Richmond, Virginia, 23261
TITLE OF PAPER: REFINEMENTS TO THE FTC PROCEDURE FOR THE QUANTITATIVE

AFFILIATION AND ADDRESS:

DETERMINATION OF TPM IN CIGARETTE SMOKE

STUDY GROUP:
ABSTRACT TEXT:

A lightweight and disposable filter holder assembly used in the collection
of - total particulate matter in cigarette smoke was developed as a replacement
for the currently used Lucite filter holder. Not only are these new holders
lighter in weight (5 grams versus 27 grams for the Lucite holder) but the
inconvenient and time-consuming steps of washing these holders in an alcohol
bath and drying prior to subsequent use are also eliminated.
During the development of these holders, it was noted that certain types
of materials, including Lucite, were very sensitive to changes in the moisture
content of the environment resulting in highly variable TPM resuits. These
variations become most significant for extremely low yield cigarettes where
negative TPM deliveries have been frequently encountered during the analysis.
A negative TPM result indicates a loss of weight of the filter assembly
the smoking procedure. These negative numbers have been obtained even when during
the filter pads were clearly stained by the smoke particulate phase indicating
that something was collected during the smoking process. Therefore, the
apparently negative TPM deliveries must be a result of an artifact in the smoke
particulate matter collection procedure. Experimental data are presented
showing that the observed artifact is primarily due to some phenomenon occurring
at - the surface of the filter holder during, but extraneous to, the particulate
matter collection process. This phenomenon is shown to be attributable to
the inherent property of certain materials, including Lucite, to easily adsorb
In order to minimize the observed bias in the TPM results and thus allow
for the collection of more meaningful data, a lightweight and disposable holder
made out of polypropylene and polystyrene was developed. In addition to the
obvious advantages of being lightweight and disposable, experimental evidence
was presented showing that a negative bias which becomes significant at low
TPM delivery levels is eliminated through the use of these holders because
of their inherent insensitivity to moisture fluctuations in the environment.

and desorb moisture from the environment.

BIG TOBACCO CANT CUT TEEN SMOKING

By. Alan Brody. Alan Brody, a marketing journalist, is the author of - Cigarette Seduction."
THE TOBACCO industry may be guilty of many big lies, but Congress and the public health community may be
developing a big lie of their own: that the cigaretie companies can undo the phenomenon of teenaged smoking.
As Stanton Glantz, author of "Cigarette Papers," wrote: "The tobacco companies know how to get kids smoking and,
But the issue is bigger than tobacco companies. Because the settlement talks with the government are based on the
tobacco companies" supposed omnipotence, the likely failure will create a whole new layer of corruption all the way
from illegal sales to fly-by-night tobacco companies to the potential for more damaging products to enter the gap.
Adults tend to have a poor memory of their own youth and why they themselves became smokers. It wasn't because
the tobacco companies marketed to them. It was because they marketed to adults and, as teenagers, they desperately
A lively grandmother in her 80s confided to me that she started smoking at 10 and quit at 40. That means she began
smoking in the 1930s when cigarette ads were still focusing on tobacco leaf quality and Turkish flavor. There were no
ads for Leenagers and certainly none for pre-teens. In fact, the country barcly paid. any attention to teens.
Conventional wisdom has it that advertising and marketing are responsible for selling tobacco. It helps. But does it
cause smoking? The absence of advertising in Finland and, for a while, in Italy showed that cigarettes sell just fine
The etiology of smoking runs deeper into the. realm of mystery than legislators and public health oflicials may care to
venture. But that is truly where the allure has its origins. Teenagers aren't responding to ads nearly so much as they are
Since we as a society have taken no steps to fill a gap in coming-of-age rituals common in other cultures, guess what
industry has come to occupy this role? Kids seck a magic path to the "real heart" of adulthood. They will accept danger
but they want belonging and a kind of personal guide, the mystical amulet popular in myth. Cigarettes offer this. That
When teenagers were invited to tell Congress why they smoke, one girl said she was: a nonsmoker until she watched a
talk show where experts cited depression as a reasons teenagers smoked. "So that's what you do!" said the girl, who
Thave no objection to taxing the tobacco companies or throwing a few perjurers in the hoosegow. But the demand for
smoking is a phenomenon that is not covered by the proposed legislation and both the tobacco companies and the public
health groups are going to be left with an embarrassing and costly predicament. As the European experience has shown,
raising prices works - for: a while and then kids have a way of: readjusting. A greater fear, as one teenager put: it in an
interview with an American Cancer Society worker I spoke with: "if you make them so expensive, we'll just go on to
In this politicized environment, iti is easy to believe that legislation can make magic. Or that the tobacco companies
are solely responsible for the rise in smoking. When the Centers for Disease Control announced that smoking had
increased 30 percent in six years, they were quite pleased because the implication is that the tobacco companies are to
blame. But this was also during the most hostile media period tobacco has ever faced. Newspapers, TV networks and
even: magazines that once quivered at the thought of losing cigarette ad dollars now thumb their noses, knowing drug

given proper economic motivation, they will know how to stop kids from smoking."

sense oe arecuor and bope from our

head of the local charity drive.
These themes have been resonating,
explicitly and implicitly, in the presiden-
tial campaign. Both President Bush and
Gov. Clinton have tried to harness the
widespread malaise among voters and
offer hope for the future, Mr. Clinton by
invoking "change" at every opportunity,
and Mr. Bush by promising that his poll-
cies are on the brink of yielding significant
A close look at several people who have
seen their confidence in the future erode
suggests why there is such widespread
disillusionment with the American dream.
But not everyone is grim. Those who have
come from the poorest backgrounds or
encountered the greatest hardships seem
to retain the most hope.
Everyone Seems Defeated'
When Mark Donnelly came of age in the
1960s, no problem seemed insoluble. In
1962, as a 20-year-old Army private, Mr.
Donnelly went to Oxford, Miss., to protect
James Meredith, whose enrollment at the
University of Mississippi sparked race
riots. For a week, Mr. Donnelly stood
outside Mr. Meredith's dormitory with a
rifle guarding him against attack. One.
student spat on him. he recalls.
Mr. Donnelly also served in Vietnam.
But after his discharge. he marched on
Washington to pro
test the war and be-
came a regional or-
ganizer for Vietnam
Vets Against the
War. While attend-
ing Columbia Uni-
versity, Mr. Don-
nelly blocked police
from entering a
building after stu-
dents had seized it.
"We were a gen-
eration that had
hoped the world
could be a better Mark Donnelly
place," says Mr. Donnelly, now a 50-year-
old vice president at Chemical Bank in
New York City. "We naively thought that
problems were solvabie."
his view is different.
Today,
lems he sees - the budget deficit, strato-
spheric health-care costs, the AIDS epi-
demic and deficient schools - seem insu-
perable. The assumption that prosperity
would cure social ills has hit the wall of
reality in the form of intractable urban
poverty and a fury that erupted in Los
Angeles this spring. The proportion of
households with annual incomes under
$15,000 was lower in 1990, after adjustment
for inflation, than in 1980 or 1970, but it
remained stubbornly close to 25%.
"I've become very cynical about the
ability of our system to bring about
change," Donnelly says. "There's a
real malaise in America right now.
Everyone seems defeated. You no longer
belleve anything's going to get done."
Though he concedes that his current

By CLARE ANSBERRY
And THOMAS F. O'BOYLE
Staff Reporters of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
For many Americans, the future seems
about as secure as a dandelion puff.
An entire generation now reaching
middle age is questioning whether they or
their children can do better than their
parents. Job security went out with three-
piece suits, and pundits have coined a new
term, aumpies - for downwardly mobile
professionals. Today, both mother and
father work, not to be rich, but to send kids
to college. The complicated family seene
looks more like an Andy Warhol canvas
than a Norman Rockwell portrait.
Statistically, Americans, both rich and
poor, are improving their lots. Their
buying power has doubled since the 1950s,
and their standard of living remains the
highest in the world. Others outside the
U.S. still believe people can improve their
lot in America: The current wave of immi-
grants is the largest since early this cen-
Even so, many Americans despair
about the ruture. In part that's because, in
relative terms, America's standard of liv-
ing isn't as far ahead of everyone else's as
it once was; other countries are catching
up. Nor is the U.S. rate of growth as rapid
as it once was. And even some affluent
Americans have discovered, as their par-
ents warned, that money doesa't buy hap
piness. The same numbers - one in three
Americans told researchers at the Na-
tional Opinion Research Center they were
"very happy" in both 1957 and 1990. No
amount of money ensures happiness, con-
cludes David G. Myers in his book "The
Pursuit of Happiness": rather, happiness
Is satisfaction with wnatever one has.
Warren Bennis, a business professor at
the University of southern California, has
another explanation for this widespread
and Mahler-like melancholy. Recalling a
sunny phrase of the 1930s - "the long sum-
mer of the future" - he says today that
feeling seems to be missing. "We want a

tury.

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN SMOKERS, EX-SMOKERS,
PASSIVE SMOKERS AND NON-SMOKERS
ALISON THORNTON, PETER LEE* and JOHN FRY
P.N. Loe Statistics and Computing Ltd, 17 Cedar Road, Sutton, Surrey SM2 SDA, England
(Received in reolsed, form 8 March 1994)
Abstract- -The extent to which current, ex- and passive smoking are associated with
other risk lactors, and the potential for confounding arising from these associations, was
studiod using a representative sample of 9003 British adults. The distribution of 33
lifestyle factors generally considered associated with adverse health were compared in
current smokers, ex-smokers, never smokers living with a smoker ("passive smokers")
and other never smokers. of the 33 risk factors 27 showed a significantly higher
prevalence in heavy smokers than in never smokers and only two showed a lower
prevalence. For many risk factors, prevalence increased with amount smoked, decreased
with time of smoking cessation and was increased in passive smokers. The possible
magnitude of bias from confounding by the risk factors is estimated. Iti is concluded that
confounding by multipke risk factors may be an important issue in smoking studies
where weak associations are observed. This applies particularly to studics investigating
the possible association of passive smoking with various health etfocts.

SUMMARY OF OBJECTIVE AND METHODOLOGY:

Isolated and defined tobacco smoke components are to be tested with respect to
their possible disruptive effects on the functions of cells and cell-organelles,
both in purely in vitro systems where the cells and cell-organelles are directly
exposed to the substance tested, and in cambined in vivo and in vitro experiments,
where functional disruptions are evaluated through camparisons of cells and
cell-organelles fram exposed and non-exposed animals. It is also planned to carry
out a number of studies using a perfusion technique in which the effect of a
substance can be studied in a campletely isolated organ provided with an
artificial circulation system. The purpose of these experiments is to obtain,
by means of greater knowledge of the basic functional disruptions which can occur
in cells and cell-organelles in short-term experiments, background material to
help facilitate the evaluation of the disruptive ettects which can occur in
camplete individuals exposed for a considerable length of time to the various
substances tested and of the cambined effects of several smoke components. The
substances to be tested are being selected in collaboration with the chemical
research at the Swedish Tobacco Co. (Asst. Professor Curt Enzell).

DATE: April 21, 1994

CORPORATION

FROM: Charles R. Wall

RE:

Document Disposal Suspension Notice

Litigation has been filed which requires us to retain certain records,
many, if not all, of which are already subject to Disposal Suspension under
the Philip Morris Records Management Program. Please make sure that
disposal of all records, regardless of the media, relating to the
manufacturing, testing and composition of tobacco, tobacco products, paper.
filter or any other material contained in relating to or used in the
manufacture, testing and composition of tobacco products is suspended.
These records should be maintained in the forms and media in which they

were originally created.

This notice also continues the suspension of the recycling of
computer, voicemail, or other electronic backup tapes which may contain
records subject to this notice or subject to prior suspension notices,
including the Appendix to the Records Management Manual titled Topics

Subject to Disposal Suspension.

If there is any question about whether a record is subject to this or any
other suspension notices, the record should be retained, pending

consideration of your legal department.

Within the next ten days a comprehensive notice will be sent
replacing prior Document Disposal Suspension Notices. That notice will
set forth all records which must be retained because of the litigation. The
notice will also address ways in which the financial burdens of retaining all

I

forms of electronic and computer records can be alleviated.

Sunmary: Specificity of 1,2-4lacylelycerol for the activation of
protein kinase C was investigated with various synthetic products.
-Staaroyl-3-arachidonylglycerol, a major species of diacylglycerol
derived from the recaptor-mediated hydrolyais of inositol phospho-
lipids, was most active, but many other diacylglycerols having
naturally occurring fatty acids were almost equally active in this
role. Hormone-sansitive lipase could produce potentially active
diacylglycerols during lipolysis. The lack of the specificity may
be reconciled with the possibility that the stearoyl-arachidonyl
spacios is the diacylglycerol with which protein kinase C indeed
comes in contact in the membrane when the receptor is stimulated,
and that diacylglycerols from other sources are produced in dig-
tinct compartments and are not intercalated into the phospholipid
It is generally accepted that receptor-mediated hydrolysis of
inositol phospholipids produces diacylglycerol for the activation
of protein kinase C to modulate many Ca**-dependent cellular
processes (1). However, the physiological picture as vell as the

Wall Street stops 10 take breather

Stocks closed slightly mixed Wednesday as the markct paused to catch its breath afler posting four straight
sessions of gains on upbeal news about the economy. The Dow. Joncs industrial average closed upjust 0.73 ofa
point al 5,625.45. An early rally to 5,673.10 stalled. just short of its record close of 5,689.74 set on April 3. Tho

Nasdaq Composite indox closed down .93 at 1233.56 on volume of 682 million shares.

Renewed optimism drives Tokyo markets

Tokyo stocks stormed higher on Wednesday and the dollar also spurted upward after an influcntial Finance
Ministry official dampencd on talk of an early rise in Japanese intcrcst rates. The benchmark Nikkei 225
average surged morc than 700 points to close at 22,055.97 as rcccnt fcars about tighter credit gave way to
optimism. Brokers said the rally confirms that stocks have relurned to a long-term upward trend after a round of

corrective selling.
-Fuil Story-

X Tobacco company proposcs deal on regulation

Philip Morris USA, the largest tobacco company in the U.S., called Wednesday for a ban on cigarctte vending
machines as well as sweeping advertising reform, including a ban on permanent tobacco ads in stadiums - but
there is a catch. The company's stipulation is that the Food and Drug Administration must be precluded from

regulating tobacco products, except for any such product making a health claim.

Company to buy 8 radio stations for $178 million

Dallas-based Chancellor Broadcasting Co. said Wednesday it signed an agreement 10 purchase cight radio
slations in Florida from privatcly held OmniAmerica Group for $178 million cash and stock. Of the total, $163
million will be paid in cash and S15 million in Chancellor Class A common shares. Once tho deal is final,

Chanccllor will operate the four leading radio stations in Orlando.

FOR USE AFTER 10 A.M., April 29, 1969

Statement of Milton B. Rosenblatt, M.D., before the House
Committee on Interstate and Foreign commerce, April 29, 1969.
Dr. Rosenblatt is visiting physician at the Metropolitan and
Coler Hospitals and associate attending physician at the Flower Fifth
Avenue Hospital, all in New York. He is a member of the Council on
Undergraduate Medical Education of the American College of Chest

Physicians.

News Summary

"The concept that cigarette smoking is the cause of the increase
in lung cancer and emphysema is a colossal blunder, " he says.
Dr. Rosenblatt points out lung cancer was well known a century
before widespread cigarette smoking. "The only thing new is our
ability to diagnose it before autopsy, " he says, pointing to only
a three percent diagnostic success before autopsy in a German
study of 178 cases between 1887 and 1900, and an 81 percent
success in a U. S. Study of 363 cases in 1949-1958.
"The increase in lung cancer is therefore a direct result of
diagnostic progress, " he reports. "It has been estimated that a
diagnostic error of five percent in males and one percent in females
among deaths attributed to pneumonia and other resplratory diseases
would have resulted in the same incidence of lung cancer in 1914
as in 1950." X-ray, bronchoscopy, surgery and sputum studies have
Dr. Rosenblatt points to the declining rate of increase in lung
cancer as being "far more compatible with diagnostic progress than 2
with a true increase." He says that "despite all the claptrap
concerning the carcinogenic effects of tar and nicotine there is
no valid experimental evidence that tobacco extract or smoke

all helped make the difference, he says.

PHILIP MORRIS STATEMENT
CIPOLLONE DECISION

REGARDING UNITED STATES SUPREME COURT

Yesterday, the United States Supreme Court rendered the long awaited

decision on the Cipollone case.

In spite of the anti-tobacco interests' efforts to make the decision seem like a
defeat for our industry, the fact is that the Court's verdict was a victory for us.

There were three basic issues in this case.

The first and most important - referred to as the issue of "failure to warn" -
revolved around the question of whether cigarette advertising and label warnings,
in effect since the 1960s, provided consumers with an adequate warning of the risk

factors associated with smoking and health.

On this most important issue, the Court ruled in our favor, and exempted
tobacco companies from post-1969 legal claims that consumers were not adequately

warned.

A second important issue was whether plaintiffs can assert claims that
normal, mainstream cigarette advertising and promotion somehow undermined
the effectiveness of the health warnings. On this issue, the Court also ruled that

post-1969 claims are preempted.

The third issue - referred to as intentional misrepresentation - related to the
question of whether tobacco companies engaged in knowing deception by concealing

from consumers information

:
c
N
o


not generally known about the risks of smoking.

SMOKING AMONG NORWEGIAN DOCTORS 1952-84
HANNE TRURMER, KJELL BJARTVEIT, ARNE HAUKNES

697

National Council on Seoking and Health, P.O. Box 8025 Dep.. Osio 1, Norway
A1984 survey on Norwegian doctors vas used to update earlier conclusions from
sinilar surveys in 1952' and 1974. The 1984 survey included for the first tim
questions regarding doctors' intervention with patients. 911 of a stratified
sample of nembers of the Norwegian Medical Assosiation responded to the mailed
questionnaire, 435 female and 969 nale physicians. As snoking varies systematic.
ally by age, the general population vas ageadjusted to natch the doctors' age
distribution. The figures given for the general population in this paper may

therefore differ from official Norwegian figures.

BEEUGISI
Seoking Habits:

In 1984, 18.61 of male doctors vere smokers, whercas in the Norwegian popula
tion at large 461 were smokers. Only 11.41 of female doctors smoked compared to
411 of all Norvegian wonen. There seeas to be a widening gap between the doctors
and the lay population, because the differences are more marked in the younger
age groups, and because nore doctors than lay persons vant to quit smoking.
In comparison both to 1952 and to 1974 there was in 1984 a turther considerable
decrease in the proportion of doctors who smoke, both within and across age
cohorts. (not the sane persons), with the exception of persons 65 years of age
and older. The decrease in smoking among males is nuch stceper among doctors
than in the Norvagian male population. Smoking proportions are increasing in
the female population, and reducing sharply among female physicians. (Fig. 1)
251 of male and 151 of female doctors are now ex-smokers, from this it nay be
inferred that 2.400 Horwegian doctors have quit seoking. The doctors who
continue smoking have not cut down on their tobacco use. The nean consumption
per smoker was 14 cigarettes per day for male doctors and 12 cigarettes per day
for female doctors. This difference is almost identical to the doctors' con-
sumption in 1974 and to the consumption of the general population in 1984.
Vhen asked to predict their snoking habits in 5 years, only 111 of male doctors
and 41 of female doctors whosmoke were certain that they would smoke in 1989,
whereas 401 of the nen and 541 of the wonen think it likely or certain that they
vill quit smoking. If their own predictions were truc, the overall rates of
smoking in 1989 vould be 111 for male doctors and 51 for female doctors.

COURT RULES KEY FLORIDA MEDICAID AGENCY
IS UNCONSTITUTIONAL; SEVERELY NARROWS
APPLICATION OF CONTROVERSIAL LAW

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 28 - A circuit judge in Tallahassee today
declared key provisions of the controversial 1994 Amendments to the Medicaid
Third-Party Liability Act unconstitutional and held that the state agency charged
with administering the state's Medicaid program is unconstitutionally structured.
Charles R. Wall, senior vice president and deputy general counsel for
Philip Morris, said the ruling should provide the basis for the dismissal of a
claim by the State of Florida. Today's ruling came in a declaratory judgment
case filed by the Associated Industries of Florida, Philip Morris Inc. and others.
"Because the court ruled that the state agency is unconstitutionally
structured, we believe that the claim based on the state's Third-Party Medicaid
Liability Act should now be dismissed," said Wall. That case is pending in

circuit court in West Palm Beach.

In addition, today's ruling clarified a crucial issue the State of Florida
sought to obscure last week in media interviews after the hearing leading to
today's ruling. The Court held that the new Medicald law applies only to
allegedly tortious conduct occurring AFTER July 1, 1994, the date the new law
In his ruling, Circuit Judge F.E. Steinmeyer said the law "may only be
applied prospectively - specifically, to conduct of potential third-party
defendants that occurred after the amendments' effective date of July 1, 1994.
No party shall be held liable under the amendments for conduct or activities that
"This could well be the beginning of the end of this lawsuit by the State
of Florida," Wall said. "The State's claims governed by the new Medicaid law
are essentially based on allegediy tortious acts occurring before the effective
date of this law and therefore cannot be the basis for any finding of liability."
The Court also declared unconstitutional the new Medicaid law's
provision that allowed the State to join together in a single lawsuit hundreds or

became etfective.

occurred before July 1, 1994."

The attached identified product test report:

1) Confirms the strong consumer appeal of the ostrich package (Soft Pack)
2) Indicates that we have two acceptable cigarettes for the pack:
The B & H product with slightly superior smoking (taste/mildness)
characteristics and the other product with lower tar numbers and
3) Shows that, although the name "Philip Morris" in general has
negative connotations for a new cigarette product, it works very
well in the situation of appearing on the elegant, somewhat feminine,

in an actual smoking situation over several days.

amore remarkable filter.

mildness connoting, ostrich pack.

Overall, the results are sufficiently encouraging to continue testing to
find the optimum combination of name, product and package style.
In January, the slim box version of the package will be tested.
At some point I think we should also test the basic B & H cigarette with
some visual point of difference. Currently the B & H product gives us only
a nice cigarette in an elegant pack. If the cigarette itself was visually
different from other cigarettes it would make it easier for the smoker to
translate his impression of the high quality package to an impression of
extra high quality cigarettes, appropriately packaged. This visual differ-
ence could be the turbo fluted filter, a recessed filter or possibly just

decoration on the tipping paper or rod.

Subject: Effect of Tween-80 and Safflower Oil, the Vehicles

for Dextromethorphan and Compound 111, on the Citric
Acid Aerosol Induced Coughing in the Guinea Pig.

The accompanying table presents additional experimental
data which may be relevant to my report of June 17, 1971, en-
titled "Antitussive Activity of Compound 111 in the Conscious
Guinea Pig". The coughing experiments were carried out as
described in the June 17, 1971 report. Essentially, where
the drugs, Compound 111, and dextromethorphan were used before,
Data in the attached table indicate that these two drug
vehicles did not enhance nor attenuate the cough responses.
Thus, as far as the data can indicate, safflower oil did not
counteract any possible antitussive effect of Compound 111,
nor did Tween-80 provide any additive effect to dextromethorphan.

their respective vehicles were used here.

The FCC said it is proposing to refuse licenses
to broadcasters who carry. cigarette advertising
because of evidence that smoking is injurious to hcalth
and the FCC has an obligation to protect the public
intercst. This is nibbling at onc corner of an issue
that is bigger than the FCC and: may, be bigger
than the Congress: the right of individuals to do
as they, please 50 long as thcy don't harm another.
Jta also is a good example of the misguided philosophy
that if you don't mention something, maybe it won't
Congressman Paul Rogers, Florida Democrat, and
chairman of the House interstate and Foreign Con-
merce Conmiticc, said in reference to the proposed
FCC rule that the ngency had oversiepped the bounds
of its author:ty. He said he doubts that FCC has
any right to tell an advertiser what he could not
say in his advertisements. Rogers said Congress will
take a cluse Icok at the whole question of regulations
on television and radio advertising content, not only
as to the Federal Communications Commission but
in regard to Federal Trade Commnission practices as
The stakes involved extend beyond the business
of broadcasling. Thcy go to the heart of whether
government bureaus should he allowed to go beyond
the limits of due proccss and the law,

Document Disposal Suspension Notice

Litigation has been filed which requires us to retain certain records,
many, if not all, of which are already subject to Disposal Suspension under
the Philip Morris Records Management Program. Please make sure that
disposal of all records, regardless of the media, relating to the manufacturing,
testing and composition of tobacco, tobacco products, paper, filter or any
other material contained in, relating to or used in the manufacture, testing
and composition of tobacco products is suspended. These records should be
maintained in the forms and media in which they were originally created.
This notice also continues the suspension of the recycling of computer,
voicemail, or other electronic backup tapes which may contain records
subject to this notice or subject to prior suspension notices, including the
Appendix to the Records Management Manual titled Topics Subject to

Disposal Suspension.

If there is any question about whether a record is subject to this or any
other suspension notices, the record should be retained, pending

consideration of your legal department.

Within the next ten days a comprehensive notice will be sent replacing
prior Document Disposal Suspension Notices. That notice will set forth all
records which must be retained because of the litigation. The notice will also
address ways in which the financial burdens of retaining all forms of

a

electronic and computer records can be alleviated.

PHYSICAL PRCPERTIES OF CIGARETE SMOKE
ARF Project No. C 593
September 25 to Oc tober 29, 1954

I. INERODEOTICN

Acditional wcrk has ceen dene on the crot.em of exma.ed sacke to

learn mere about the prysical properties of cigarette smoke. Interesting re-
suits ha ve beccme evailable on the question of residual smoke in the lungs
after smoking hes stopped. The smoking machine was rebuilt, and a movie and
still pic tures were taken in prepara tion for the sumnary report.

II. EXHALED SMOKE

Aa pointed out in PR 11, some smoke ia exhaled in the course of nor-

mal brea thing following the first exhalation after a puff. It was found that
this residual smoke could be sampled by directly passing a smoker's exhaled
breath through an impinger. The atmospheric dust particles collected at the
same time seriously interfered with the saoke particles on the impinger slide.
therefore, steps were taken to reduce the inpingement of dust particies to a,-
minimum. The exhaled breath is mixed with a large volune of very dry,
filtered air. This prevents condensation on the dust particles in the jet
owing to the expansion of the gas. netted particles atick very well to the
glass slide while dry particles are blow off. Also, the width of the high
capacity jet was selectad s0 that the very smallest dust particles would not
be impinged officiently. Furthermore, it has been noted that the silicone
ccating en the microscope slides reduces the sticking probability of solid

particles.

Title: Epidemic by the Numbers

Dr. Marvin A. Kastenbaum is currently the director of

statistics at the Tobacco Institute in Washington, D.C. Prior
to. assuming this position he was with the department of
statistics at Stanford. He has also been on the faculty of
the University of Wisconsin and has worked for Oak Ridge
National Laboratory, the Institute of Human Biology at the
University of Michigan, and the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission.
He is a fellow of ASA, the Royal Statistical Society, and
American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Abstract

overuse of the term "epidemic" by well-meaning public

officials and members of the scientific establishment may
ultimately yield a diminishing response from the citizenry at
whom. it is directed. How often can "Epidemic" be proclaimed
throughout the land before the inhabitants thereof react as if

The Boy were crying, "Wolf," again?

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

Smoking Is Probably Not Associated With Heart Dis sease,
Swedish Scientists Find; Heredity Implicated

Washington - Both the tendency to smoke, and susceptibility to

respiratory symptams and heart disease, may be due to inherited constitutional
differences between people, according to a series of Swedish studies reportea

in Tobacco and Health Research.

The publication digests scientific papers on subjects related to

tobacco use and health, from medical and technical journals throughout the

world. It is published by the Tobacco Institute.

Two of the Swedish investigators, it notes, concluded that cigarette

smoking is probably not associated with coronary heart disease, high blood

pressure or high blood cholesterol levels.

TEHR also reports that lung cancer of all types has been found to be

three to four times more common in the Occidental European-American) immigrant
population of Israel than in the Oriental (Asian-African) immigrants, even

though smoking is about the same in both groups.

And an international survey of eight major metropolitan areas, an

English study found, turned up data called by the author incomprenensible
according to current ideas as to how smoking affects lung cancer incidence."

Genetics and the Heart

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

James Snapp, insurance broker and former Mayor of
El Cajon, today urged his friends and neighbors to support
Californians for Common Sense in the organization's fight
against the smoking prohibitions proposition, Proposition 5,

on the November ballot.

"The burden on California taxpayers has reached the
limit," Snapp said. "The people, through Proposition 13,

said they don't want this kind of spending.

"Now comes the smoking prohibitions proposition that
will be on our November ballot. It would cost an additional
$43 million in local and state tax money to pay for an enormous
system of expensive signs (at every entrance to every facility of
every state and local governmental entity), law enforcement and

court costs.

"This additional tax load is not necessary. I am supporting
Californians for Common Sense to defeat this needless and costly

initiative."

Co-chairmen of Californians for Common Sense, the organization
campaigning for defeat of Proposition 5, are Houston I. Flournoy,
dean of the University of Southern California Center for Public
Affairs, Katherine B. Dunlap, prominent conservationist and civic $
leader and John F. Henning, executive secretary-treasurer of the -

:

California Labor Federation (AFL-CIO).

MICHAEL A. MILES REMARKS
ECONOMIC CLUB OF CHICAGO
Tuesday, February 9, 1993

Thank you

and thank you ladies and gentlemen. It's a pleasure to

be here. When I was invited to speak to you, la asked ira what you might like to
hear me talk about. He said that I could talk about anything I wanted to, as long

as Isaid something reallyinteresting.

This reminded me of an occasion back in the 1960's, when the comedian
Mort Sahl was introduced by a master of ceremonies who said, "Come on out,
This kind of introduction is, of course, a comedian's kiss of death, but Sahl,
who was both ultra-liberal and irreverently anti-establishment, was up to the
occasion. He came out, looked at the MC, looked at the audience, and said

Mort, and say something really funny."

"John Foster Duiles." This brought down the house.

Well, I've been called on to say something really interesting, and while it's
probably not house-bnnging-down matenial, I hope some of it will be interesting to

you.

There are two subjects I'd like to touch on this evening.
First, because I've discovered that Philip Morris' size and mix of
businesses make it the object of considerable public interest, l'd like to give you a
brief overview of the company, and the strategies by which we are managing it.
Second, I'd like to take a few minutes to talk about what I will call "science
fiction," the problems that this science fiction creates for businesses in general
and our business in particular, and some thoughts about what can be done to

solve, or at least lessen, these problems.

Tol begin with, then, let me tell you a little about Philip Morris.
In its combined operations, Philip Morris is probably the world's largest
consumer packaged goods company. In its component parts, PM is also the
worid's largest international cigarette company, the second largest food company
Last year, revenues for our worldwide operations totaled a little more than
59 billion dollars, which we expect will again put us in the top ten on Fortune's
list of the largest industrial companies when that list is published in
We have 166,000 employees working in 1,100 facilities in 160 countries
around the worid. They produce. literally thousands of different consumer
packaged products, selling under hundreds of different brand names.

and the third largest beer company.

STAFF AT PHILIP MORRIS RESEARCH CENTER
CONSISTS OF LEADING SCIENTISTS IN MANY FIELDS

RESEARCH CENTER TOWER OFFERS RESEARCH FLEXIBILITY
AND AN ATMOSPHERE OF SCIENTIFIC FREEDOM

At Philip Morris's Research Center in Richmond, Va. tobacco
and its various smoke compounds undergo every type of analysis
under the survelllance of a professional staff of 190, including
40 Ph.D.'s. Total personnel at the Research Center is expected
to be about 400 when the new Research Center Tower is completed in

late 1972.

Every relevant scientific discipline is represented by one
or more persons on the research staff, and sometimes by entire
teams of specialists. Fields of investigation include all ap-
propriate branches of chemical and physical analysis, including
smoke chemistry, chromatography, spectrophotometry, cigarette
technology, biochemistry, agronomy, microbiology, psychology,

filter development, flavor formulation,

psychodynamics of smoking,

organic chemistry, isolation and identification of volatile flavoring 5

constituents, and many others.

SUMMARY FOR KOOL "HOTLINE" PROJECT

In the 1st quarter of 1985, the Consumer Affairs
Department plans to initiate a toll free number for our
KOOL smokers to phone in their complaints and inquiries.
Attached for your information are various pieces of
background materials, such as the initial proposal, a
summary of reasons for a "Hot Line", and follow up memos
Mr. Blott reviewed this material and has recommended that
we push forward with the 800 number. He suggested that we
pursue the project by placing the toll free number on the
carton, because that method will reach the most important
Funding of $132,404 for the 800 number will be provided in
the 1985 Marketing Administration G & A Budget.
Please review the attached documents and if you have any
questions or suggestions regarding this project, call me
as soon as possible to ensure your concerns are given as
much time and consideration as necessary before

NEW SURVEY OF ADVERTISING INDUSTRY TAKES ON HOT TOPIC:

TOBACCO ADVERTISING AND CHILDREN

Some surprising results from the first-ever survey of advertising
agencies about the role their industry plays in marketing tobacco
products to children will be announced at a press conference in
New York City on Dec. 18. Among the questions, rank-and-file
members were asked their feelings about the influence of tobacco
advertising on youth, and if they agree with provisions of the
FDA rule to restrict the marketing and sales of cigarettes and
The survey was sponsored by the Initiative on Tobacco Marketing
to Children, a group of advertising, marketing and public
relations executives concerned about tobacco marketing to young
The advertising industry recently announced it is considering
imposing a voluntary code of conduct and establishing a unit to
review ads for tobacco, liquor and other products that could

Dear Dietrich:

-Dr. Spears sent me your letter concerning the removal
of nitrosamines by acetate filters. This sounds interesting
I wish I had thought of it. Anyway, we will be happy to
supply you with whatever cigarettes you may need for this work.
If I may, I would like to suggest comparison of the follow-
ing four samples. 1) 85mm, typical U.S. blend cigarettes with
25mm cellulose acetate filters. 2) 85mm, same blend with 10mm
acetate filter (we will replace other 15mm with a plastic tube).
3) 85mm same blend with 25mm filter and 25-308 air dilution.
4) 85mm same blend without filter (achieved by pulling filter

plugs from number 1) above.

If significant differences are tound in these samples, we
may then want to talk about further studies to explore this in
more detail. Please let me know if the above suggestion is
suitable or if you have something else in mind, and how many

cigarettes you will need for the experiment.

Very truly yours,
Tiedl
F.J. Schultz

PROJECT NAME: CO REMOVAL USING INORGANIC SALTS

BUDGET:

$16,639

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: : Principle Project Objectives The principle objective of this study is

to evaluate carbon monoxide removal from cigarette smoke using ash or
components of ash. The carbon monoxide removal from smoke using ashes,
such as coal, paper, wood and tobacco will be optimized. The minerals in
the ashes will be determined to elucidate the mechanism responsible for
the carbon monoxide removal. The effect of ash addition on cigarette
taste and tar and nicotine levels will be evaluated. A procedure for
ash addition which is effective, condusive to mass production of cigarettes

and acceptable to consumers, will be examined.

AMMONIA DETERMINATION

When cigarette smoke is drawn through a Cambridge filter very
little ammonia or ammonium salts are detected. Possibly the ammonia
in the first puff comes through the filter. After the first puff the
increasing deposit of acids on the filter combines with the ammonia
and removes it from the gas strcam. When no Cambridge filter is used,
95% free ammonia and ammonium salts are collected in 80 ml of .018 N H2s04.
Since the concentration of ammonia in cigarette smoke is quite low
compared to the amount of acetic, formie and other acids present, we do

not feel that the 40-70 ug./cig. represents free ammonia.

Procedure - Two charcoal filter cigarettes are smoked for each determination.
The smoke is dispersed through 80 ml of .018 N H2S04 in a specially designed
trap by means of a coarse fritted disc. The solution is added to a 100 ml
volumetric flask containing about 1.5 gm. of permutit. The permutit has
been screened and washed 3 times with 25 ml portions of water. The flask
is shaken for 15 minutes on a Burrel wrist action shaker. If the desired
agitation is not achieved, the flask is shaken by hand. The acid solution
is poured off and the permutit is washed 3 times with 25 ml portions of
distilled water. Five ml of water and 1 ml of 10% NaoH is added to the
permutit. The flask is shaken again for 5 minutes. The addition of 60-70
ml water 1s followed by 3 ml Nesslers reagent. The flask is filled to the
mark with water, inverted many times for mixing, and allowed to stand 30

I

minutes.

00073440

Blank - The blank is processed in the same manner as the sample; except, of
course, the .018 N H2S04 solution contains no dissolved smoke.

Date: February 17, 1982

Weekly Meeting with New Products Development

Objectives: Smoke and evaluate samples prepared during the week preceeding
Conclusions: Two sets of samples containing chocolate filler were smoked.
One set contained a mixed fruit flavor in the tube walls, and the other set
had an apple flavor with high boiling point tobacco flavors in the tube
Both sets of samples were attached to 2.5/ 48 C.A. filters diluted by about
The concentration of the fruit flavors which were included in the extrusion
mixture for each sample were felt to be too high. The fruity notes were
described as being overpowering. It was felt by some that the dilution was
too great and had reduced the volume of smoke delivery too much.
Five additional sets of samples were smoked. These samples had no filler
inside of the tubes. Flavorants were added to the tube wall mixtures prior
to extrusion for each set. The reactions to each were as follows:
Anise flavor - Strong pack aroma, no detectable sidestream contribution,
Fire-cured tobacco flavor - Chocolate-cooked tobacco-like pack aroma,
no detectable sidestream contribution, no detectable flavor contribution.
Oriental tobacco flayor - Green pack aroma, sharp green sidestream aroma,
Black cigar tobacco flavor - No contribution to pack aroma, no detectable
sidestream contribution, woody, cellulosic chemical flavor.
Burley tobacco flavor - Fermented mowed weeds aroma, tobacco-like sidestream
not objectionable. Flavor similar to aroma of rotten weeds.
Chris Kounnas pointed out that since these samples had no filler and produced
little smoke, the concentration of flavors delivered was probably too great for
the quantity of smoke delivered. It was therefore difficult to evaluate the
compatibility of these flavorants with extruded tobacco smoke.
Plans: The chocolate flavored extruded filler will be used as a standardi
method to generate greater quantities of smoke for flavorant evaluations in
Bill Bell will produce some of the above flavorants in reduced concentrations

PSYCHOSOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS OF ADOLESCENT
SMOKERS BEFORE THEY STARTED SMOKING:
EVIDENCE OF SELF-SELECTION
APROSPECTIVE: STUDY
CARL C. SELTZER and FRANK W. OECHSLI

Peabody Muscum. Harvard U'niversity. Cambridge. MA 02138 and the Child Health and
Development Studics, School of Public Health. University of California, Berkcley..

CA 94720. U.S.A.
(Recrired in rerised, form 17 dagust 1984)

Abstract- Evidence of noncomparability of sell-formed smoker and nonsmoker groups of
adolescents from the Child Health and Development Studies of the University of California.
Berkeley. was found in a study of antecedent psychosocial characteristics (observed at age 10)
before the adoption of the smoking habit. With possible confounding factors controlled, eventual
smokers showed significantly greater prevalence than nonsmokers of Type A personality traits.
extraversion. psychoticism. anger. andi restless sleep. Eventual smokers were lower in socio-
cconomic status than nonsmokers. and also exhibited signihcantly lower mean scores fon the
Raven Progressive Matrices and Peabody Picture Vocabulary tests. For each trait. the. trends of
the data were consistent in boys and girls Since many of these traits are shown to "track" into
adult life. where they are then related to coronary heart disease. the role of self-sclection requires
further consideration in causal inferences about smoking and coronary heart discuse.

INTRODUCTION

INIR RECENT years. many published studies have shown an association that suggests a role
for psychosocial factors in the pathogenesis of CHD [1. 2]. In the Framingham Study.
univariate and multivariate analyses showed a positive relationship of certain psycho-
social factors to CHD and also to cigurette smoking [3-5]. The pervasive question. of
temporal precedence and u priori sell-sclection still requires further clarification. however.
In the absence of controlled experiments. the ellects of cigarette smoking on health have
been inferred from observational studies that compare persons who smoke: with
nonsmokers. In these comparisons. the disease outcomes are assumed to occur in cohorts
ofsmokers and nonsmokers who were initially similar in all relevant characteristics except
for the difference in smoking habit. Very little evidence has been available, however. to
The unique data of the Child Health and Development Studies (CHDS) of the
University of Califomia, Berkeley. provide an opportunity to check this assumption by
examining antecedent characteristics associated with teenage smoking [6-8]. The CHDS
isa prospective investigation of children from birth to late adolescence. At various stages
of their development, the children were examined as to their biological, social. and
In this report. we have analyzed the antecedent psychosocial characteristics of a large
cohort of boys and girls before some of them later began cigarette smoking as teenagers.
Reprint requests should be addressed to: Frank W. Oechsli, Child Health and Development Studies.
This project was supported: by Grant 3447 from the Peabody Museum. Harard U'niversity

NEWS RELEASE BULLETIN: NEVADA

May 15, 1999

Nevada Attorney General Frankie Sue Del Papa issued a letter to about 60 cigarette
wholesalers in the state. The letter warned that those wholesalers who do not set up escrow
accounts, into which they are required to pay $1.88 per carton for potential judgements
stemming from the sale of cigarettes made by uon-signatories or gray-market cigarettes,
will face significant fines. The fines are up to three times the amount the wholesalers are
required to pay into the escrow accounts. Also, the Attorney General stated that a
wholesaler may be banned from selling cigarettes within the state of Nevada if be commits

more than one violation.

Vevada's "Model Statute Legislation" became effective on May 24, 1999.

In the opinion of Carolina Tobacco Company, trademark owaer and sole importer of
"ROGER" brand cigarettes, the Nevada state authoritles will have 00 choice but to go after
tbe wholesalers/jobbers of gray-market cigarettes. There is no process within the Master
Settlement Agreement to catitle state authorities to seek compensation from the signatories
of the Master Settlement Agreement for the sale of cigarettes originally manufactured for
export within their state. Carolina Tobacco Company is also of the opinion that Nevada
state authorities, as well as other state authorities, will turn to wholesalers/jobbers of
cigarettes manufactured by non-signatories. State authorities will be obligated to do sO
under the terms of the Master Settlement Agreemeut, if they are unable to obtain

compensation from the aon-signatory manufacturers themselves.

for the searchable computerized database of over 1,000 medical meetings and
exhibitions, both major and minor events. Bulk quantity discounts were also
The unique directory can be instantly rearranged alphabetically,
chronologically, or by zip or area code. Mail labels and mail merge letters can
be printed. It can also be arranged by meeting topic, medical specialty,
organization sponsor, acronym, city, country, number of attendees, etc.
The directory includes totally new listings of local, regional and
international association trade exhibitions, meetings, conventions, courses,
seminars and symposia, says David Anast, publisher/editor. Key subject areas
cover the entire medical industry: medical device, biomed, biotech, equipment,
instruments, pharmaceuticals, managed care, research, hospitals and providers,
The special pre-publications, pre-payment price is $45 for the printed version
+$5 s/h ($10 for non-U.S.) +7.75% tax for Calif. residents only. Bulk quantity:

this special price offer. Orders are scheduled to ship at year-end via 1st Class

PRESS RELEASE

Embargoed untll 11:00am Thursday 23rd May 1996

NEW REPORT ON HEALTH EFFECTS OF INDOOR AIR POLLUTION

A major new report Into the health offocts of some key indoor air pollutants in the home, pub-
lished today (23/5/96), suggests that house dust mites and nitrogen dioxide (from gas cook-
ers) are likely to be the greatest source of airborne health problems in the home.
The report, EHAssessment on Indoor. Air Quality in the Home, was produced for the
Departmient of the Environment by the Medical Research Council's institute for Environment
and Health In Leicester. It looks at five types of pollutants in the home - nitrogen dioxide
(NO2), formaldehyde, volatile organic compounds (including benzene and common solvents),
house dust mitos and fungi and bacteria. Using data trom the Building Research
Establishment, also released in a report today, it evaluates the potential adverse health
effects of these poliutants and puts the findings In a national and international perspectivo.
The report recognises that the risks to health from dust mites and nitrogen dioxide are not
known, but nonetheless recommends a reduction in oxposure. Whilst the other pollutants
studied may be hazardous, the report concludes that there is no evidence that current levels
in UK homes pose a risk to health. But, as a general principle, it recommends reducing the

HEOINE

levels of indoor pollutants as a prudent measure.

As well as taking an overview of current knowledge, the report Identifies a number of Impor-
tant areas for future research. These include studies to: evaluate the potontial health bonetits -
from reducing levels of dust mites; establish clearly whether or not high NO2 leveis cause

RATHKE NAMED CEO BURSON-MARSTELLERICANADA
PITTSBURGH OFFICE ANNOUNCES NEW GENERAL MANAGER

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 - Sheila Wells Rathke, a 17-year veteran of
Burson-Marsteller and general manager of the Pittsburgh office for the past
seven years, has been named Chief Executive Officer of Burson-Marsteller's
Canadian operations. As part of Rathke's expanded responsibilities, she will be
in charge of developing and servicing business and overseeing all operational
aspects of Burson-Marsteller's offices in Toronto, Montreal, Ottawa and

Vancouver, effective December 1.

Laura Gongos, a senior vice president and 14-year veteran of Burson-Marsteller/
Pittsburgh, will succeed Rathke as general nanager of the Pittsburgh office.
"These appointments represent logical transitions for two individuals who have
made important contributions to Burson-Marsteller," said Don Cogman,
President and Chief Executive Officer, Burson-Marsteller/Americas. "Sheila has
shown tremendous skills in building and serving business in the Pittsburgh

Mr. William H. Webb, Chief Operating Officer of Philip Morris
Companies Inc., is pleased to announce the appointment of Mr. Jean-
Claude Kunz, Vice President Central Europe, to the position of
President EEMA Region, effective immediately. In his new role, Jean-
Claude will report to Mr. Andreas Gembler, President of Philip Morris
Jean-Claude began his career with Philip Morris EEMA in 1983 as
Business Development Analyst. In 1984, he was promoted to General
Manager Eastern Europe and in 1986, he was appointed General Manager
for the Levant and parts of the Middle East. In 1990, he was
appointed Area Director Eastern Europe and in 1992, Area Director
Central Europe. In 1993, he was appointed to his current position of
Vice President Central Europe. Jean-Claude has played a key role in
the success of EEMA's acquisitions and the development of the
emerging markets of Central Europe and the Balkans.
With the transfer of the domestic Scandinavian and Finnish markets to
Scandinavia / Finland / Baltics / Duty Free will assume responsibility
for Central Europe and is appointed Vice President Switzerland, Central
PHans Fluri, Vice President Eastern Europe, will assume additional
responsibility for the Baltics and is appointed Vice President Eastern

International Inc.

the EU:

PC Georges Diserens, Vice President Switzerland,

Europe and Duty Free.
Europe and the Baltics.
Also reporting to Jean-Claude will be:
P Rudi Schweizer, Senior Vice President
P John Guarino, Director Africa and Levant
P Jacques Guyot, Vice President Operations
P Kathleen Linehan, Vice President Corporate Affairs
P Turhan Talu, Vice President GCC. and Turkey
P Jean-Michel Toinet, Vice President Marketing

Please join us in congratulating Jean-Claude and in wishing him every
success in his new position as President EEMA Region. At the same
time, join us in extending our best wishes to Georges and Hans in

their new responsibilitics.

Concerned Citizen
April 1998
The Honorable
Office Address
Washington, D.C.
Dear Senator
or
Representative

United States Senate/or/United States House ofl Representatives

Ia am writing to express my: strong opposition to S. 1415, Senator John McCain's
tobacco legislation. As a concerned citizen, I am offended by many aspects of this
legislation, including unfair taxes, the creation of a black market and sweeping FDA

authority.

The McCain bill constitutes modem day Prohibition. The FDA would have
discretion under the McCain legislation to ban tobacco products immediately - without
any Congressional action. The FDA is an unelected federal agency that should not be
given unfettered authority to ban tobacco. Tobacco prohibition would foster an
immediate black market and smuggling operations -creating a boon for organized crime.
A ban on tobacco products also would be a crippling blow on many communities
whose economic stability depends on the tobacco industry. Hundreds of thousands of
people have jobs linked to the production, distribution and retailing oftobacco products.
High cigarette taxes will cause job losses in every sector of the tobacco industry - from

the seedbed to the sales counter.

I am a hard-working taxpayer, and I support legislation that keeps tobacco
products out of the hands ofminors. However, I strongly oppose any bill that infringes
on an adult's right to smoke a legal product. Adults make up 98 percent of all smokers in
the United States, and they will bear the burden of the huge tax increases proposed by

Senator McCain.

Iencourage you to vote against the McCain bill and any legislation that mirrors
the devastating effects of the McCain bill. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Respectfully,

TO: Joe Inman

Tommy Hickman

Re: Cost Management

Joe & Tommy,

In follow-up to our discussion last Friday, Iwant to make sure
how we are going to address complexity reduction with our products.
My understanding was that you two were going to work with Steve
Quiggle to come up with a list of items we want to pursue. This list
would include things Tommy already has on his list, Ron Willard's list,
etc. You were also going to try and quantify both the potential

savings and the timing.

Please let me know if my assumption is right or wrong. This is
an area we need to make sure is covered. lam also going to get with
Rob about laying out a leat/by-products strategy for the next five

years.

Jim

Subject: Video Cassette Promotion Concepts

The purpose of this memo is to forward a perspective on the potential
tie-in of RJRT and MGM/UA for the purpose of leveraging this union with
impactful consumer promotions utilizing pre-recorded video cassettes.
In December 1987, focus groups were held in Atlanta to determine how
CAMEL and Marlboro smokers would react to promotions which include
pre-recorded video cassette films from Paramount Studios. This tie-in
with Paramount was identical in concept to the proposed tie-in with
The findings of these focus groups, although qualitative, in a single
market, from a small sample, etc., illustrated a major lack of interest
in buying video movies even at a discount price when they can be rented

Background

MGM/UA.

-

so cheaply and sO conveniently.

e

Perspective

According to 1987 Simmons data, a high percentage of adult smokers own a
VCR (38.7), however, only 18% of these VCR owners have ever bought a
pre-recorded video cassette. An extremely large majority (97%) rent

movies because:

Rentals are cheap. Current movies can be rented for $2 or $3 and
if they want to retain it, they can just record it on a blank

tape.

Hit titles are readily available.
Most only watch a movie once.

Rentals are extremely accessible. Most are rented where
cigarettes are not sold but are becoming more available in
supermarkets, drug stores and convenience stores.

DATE

June 19, 1963

SUBJECT

Nicotine Production: Suggestions for an Exploratory

Program.

1. Introduction:

In my memorandum of 21 May, 1963, "Possible sources of nicotine", I compared
the merits of obtaining nicotine from a specialty crop of N. rustica as against
producing it from stalks left in the field. The conclusion was that if nicotine
were to be produced it should be produced from a crop grown for that purpose.
Recently, I came across a publication which explores this very question in some
On the basis of the results presented it becomes possible to formulate a

detail and confirms our preliminary conclusions.

pilot program which is presented below for your consideration.

2. - Summary of Prior Field Trials:

The experiences of the U.S.D.A., covering the period 1929-1938, in Browing
tobacco as a source of nicotine are collected in U.S.D.A. Technical Bulletin
No. 820, June 1942. This publication is available in the A.T.C. library under
catalog No. T-7445 hence only the pertinent highlights will be reiterated here.
a. Available nicotine from commercial types of tobacco, if entire leaf crop
b. N. rustica, var. Brasilia, consistently yiclded 150 lbs. or more per
acre when grown on fertile, moist soils. The whole plant of N. rustica can be
used for extraction whereas stalks of commercial tobaccos, owing to their high
degree of lignification, are not easily disrupted for extraction.
c. The comparative tests were conducted in field plots widely scattered
around the country, including plots in Virginia (Bowling Green and Arlington),
Pennsylvania, Wisconain, Missouri, Oregon, California, North Carolina, Tennessee
and a few others. As a result a wide variety of soils and climatic conditions
d. When grown on typical soils of the dark-fired area, or in extreme
southern regions, N. rustica did not outyield standard commercial varieties.
However, when grown on moist land approaching well-drained river bottom lands,
it yielded in excess of 100 lbs.of nicotine per acre even in these regions,

were used for extraction, would be be tween 20-40 lbs. per acre.

werc compared.

Does Bermuda 100 fit the latter category?
3. Suggested Course of Action:

If the project is to be pursucd further, the following steps are recommended:
a. Allocate 1 or 2 test acres of land within the next 8 weeks so that land
b. In spring of 1964, divide the test area into an appropriate number of
scatcered plots s0 that at least 2000 plants could be grown. N, rustica can be

preparation could be started this fall.

Dear Mr. Watson:

This letter, when countersigned below, will constitute the agreement ("Agreement")
between Structural Display, Inc. ("Contractor") and Philip Morris Incorporated ("PM
USA") pursuant to which Contractor will perform services in connection with the Philip
Morris USA C-Store Top-to-Top Meeting (the "Meeting") to be held September 18-21,
1997 at the Marriot Castle Harbour Resort in Tuckers Town, Bermuda, which will include

the following, for PM USA under the terms and conditions stated.

I.

Services
Contractor will:

(a) provide general maintenance, shipping, packing and handling P.O.S.
(b) install and dismantle materials, including back bar merchandising units,

units, set-up and dismantle C-store display on-site in Bermuda;
non self-service counter displays and retail counter with mock register;

(c) rent 20' pipe and drape; and

(d) provide project management services at the Meeting.
Contractor will be available to meet at reasonable times with PM USA
representatives at. PM USA headquarters in New York or other locations as designated by
PM USA. Contractor will perform in a professional manner throughout the term of the

Agreement.
2.
Payment

Int full and complete consideration for the services rendered by Contractor pursuant
tol Paragraphs 1(a)-(d), PM1 USA will pay Contractor an amount not to exceed $4,241 upon
PM USA's receipt of a detailed invoice and final reconciliation following complete
performance of the agreement to the. reasonable satisfaction of PM USA.

ABSTRACT

A series of four independent, two-stage SENCAR: mouse skin painting bioassays were conducted
with cigarette smoke condensates to examine the tumor promotion potential of 150 flavoring
ingredients commonly used in the manufacture of American-style blended cigarettes. Groups
consisting of 30 to 50 female SENCAR mice each were used; animals were treated once
dermally with 50 ug 0f7,12-dimethylbenza/-anthracene as a tumor initiator. One week later,
and thrice weekly for the next 26 weeks, mice received either 10 or 20 mg of smoke condensate
from Test cigarettes containing mixtures of cigarette tobacco flavoring ingredients. For
comparison, separate groups of mice were treated concurrently with smoke condensates prepared
from Reference cigarettes having similar construction and tobacco blend, but without added
flavoring ingredients. Negative and positive controls were treated with either acetone or 12-0-
etradecanoyl-phorbol-13-acetate as promoters, respectively. Virtually all mice treated with the
positive control material developed tumors and died prior to the scheduled study termination
points. Background tumor formation and mortality were very low in all negative control groups.
Survival rates and terminal body weights of mice treated with condensate samples from Test
cigarettes were not significantly different from mice treated with condensates from Reference
cigarettes. Similarly, the incidence of animals with actual tumors (grossly observable tumors at
study termination), incidence of animals with cumulative tumor (maintained count of all tumors
present for three consecutive weeks during hestudy), latency of cumulative tumors and tumor
multiplicity in mice exposed to condensates from Test cigarettes with flavoring ingredients were
not different from,values obtained with mice treated with Reference cigarette condensate. The
results indicate that the addition of the flavoring ingredients to cigarette tobacco had no
discernible effect on common indices oft tumorigenic response normally associated with mouse
skin painting bioassays using non-flavored cigarette smoke condensates.

FILE

The presence of different monooxygenase activities has been docu-
mented in human placental microsomes. The predominating cytochrome P-
450, that of androgen aromatase, catalyzes the biosynthesis of estrogens [1).
Aromatase P-450 has been the object of numerous studies to determine its
mechanism of action and to purify it (2, 3). Gough et al. 14) reported the
prcscnce of another enzyme system which catalyzes the hydroxylation of
xenobiotic substances. It has also been reported that a placental cytochrome
P-450 is responsible for the hydroxylation of benzola)pyrene via aryl hydro-
carbon hydroxylase (5-7). The low content of the responding cytochrome P-
450 in human placenta and instability during purification have made it
difficult to isolate any other active P-450 enzyme. As a side beneft gained
from our procedure to purify and characterize catalytically active aromatase
P-450 (3), we found a fraction from the immunoafinity chromatography
which showed a high level of xenobiotic activity with little contaminating
aromatase activity. Through the use ofconventional purification procedures,
we obtained a xenobiotically active P-450 with no aromatase activity.
Previous studies on aryl hydrocarbon bydroxylase activity have demon-
strated higher levels of this activity in smokers but not in nonsmokers (8, 9).

David Satcher. MD, PhD. is the Director, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
and Administrator of the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR). He
As Director of the CDC. Dr. Satcher leads the agency of the US Public Health Service
responsible for promoting health and preventing disease, injury, and premature death. The
CDC's 11 Centers. Institute and Program Ottices work closely with local, state and other
federal agencies to protect the public health. As Administrator of ATSDR. Dr. Satcher
administers the PHS agency created by the Superfund law to prevent or mitigate adverse
human health effects and diminished quality of life resulting from exposure to hazardous
Dr. Satcher, President of Meharry Medical College since 1982, was named director designate
of the CDC in August. Prior to joining Meharry. he served as professor and chairman of the
Department of Community and Family Medicine at the Morehouse School of Medicine in
He has received wide recognition in his career. He was elected to the Institute of Medicine
of the National Academy of Sciences in 1986: for his leadership skills, he received the Watts
Grassroots Award for Community Leadership in 1978, the National Conference of Christians
and Jews Award in 1985, and the "Nashvillian of the Year" award in 1992.
